repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
## Problem

If a `vim.lsp.config` explicitly sets `exit_timeout`, that indicates the config wants that behavior for most usages of `:stop()`.

Followup to #36750 

## Solution

Update `:stop()` to use `force=exit_timeout` if `force` was not explicitly passed.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
• |Client:stop()| now accepts a numerical `timeout` argument to be
```
Since this is already a new feature there's no need to mention previous iterations of the design.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -274,15 +274,16 @@ LSP
 • Support for `textDocument/onTypeFormatting`: |lsp-on_type_formatting|
   https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specification/#textDocument_onTypeFormatting
 • The filter option of |vim.lsp.buf.code_action()| now receives the client ID as an argument.
-• |Client:stop()| now accepts a numerical `force` argument to be interpreted as the time to wait
-  before forcing the shutdown.
+• |Client:stop()| now accepts a numerical `timeout` argument (renamed from `force`) to be

comment_data.body:
[The `force` argument exists in 0.11](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/9fa7c0a04638ee3d5fefbdcec347b1c07a5ce9ce/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/client.lua#L808), it just only accepts a boolean. The intention of the part in parenthesis is to document that the argument is being renamed, in addition to the new behavior it gains.

If you think it's an unnecessary detail though (the name change doesn't affect user code), I can remove that part.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -274,15 +274,16 @@ LSP
 • Support for `textDocument/onTypeFormatting`: |lsp-on_type_formatting|
   https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specification/#textDocument_onTypeFormatting
 • The filter option of |vim.lsp.buf.code_action()| now receives the client ID as an argument.
-• |Client:stop()| now accepts a numerical `force` argument to be interpreted as the time to wait
-  before forcing the shutdown.
+• |Client:stop()| now accepts a numerical `timeout` argument (renamed from `force`) to be

comment_data.body: Given how Lua doesn't have the concept of named arguments (like C# does with `renameVar(old="old", new="new")`) this isn't a breaking change to devs following `master`, and so renaming arguments shouldn't (in my very humble opinion, I'm open to debate here) be included in `news`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -274,15 +274,16 @@ LSP
 • Support for `textDocument/onTypeFormatting`: |lsp-on_type_formatting|
   https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specification/#textDocument_onTypeFormatting
 • The filter option of |vim.lsp.buf.code_action()| now receives the client ID as an argument.
-• |Client:stop()| now accepts a numerical `force` argument to be interpreted as the time to wait
-  before forcing the shutdown.
+• |Client:stop()| now accepts a numerical `timeout` argument (renamed from `force`) to be

comment_data.body: Don't think we should rename this. `force` is more intuitive and meaningful as a dual boolean/integer, vs `timeout`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1653,7 +1653,7 @@ Lua module: vim.lsp.client                                        *lsp-client*
                                 See |Client:notify()|.
       • {cancel_request}        (`fun(self: vim.lsp.Client, id: integer): boolean`)
                                 See |Client:cancel_request()|.
-      • {stop}                  (`fun(self: vim.lsp.Client, force: boolean|integer?)`)
+      • {stop}                  (`fun(self: vim.lsp.Client, timeout: integer|boolean?)`)

comment_data.body: I prefer `timeout` so it matches `exit_timeout`, but I can go either way.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1653,7 +1653,7 @@ Lua module: vim.lsp.client                                        *lsp-client*
                                 See |Client:notify()|.
       • {cancel_request}        (`fun(self: vim.lsp.Client, id: integer): boolean`)
                                 See |Client:cancel_request()|.
-      • {stop}                  (`fun(self: vim.lsp.Client, force: boolean|integer?)`)
+      • {stop}                  (`fun(self: vim.lsp.Client, timeout: integer|boolean?)`)

@@ -274,15 +274,16 @@ LSP
 • Support for `textDocument/onTypeFormatting`: |lsp-on_type_formatting|
   https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specification/#textDocument_onTypeFormatting
 • The filter option of |vim.lsp.buf.code_action()| now receives the client ID as an argument.
-• |Client:stop()| now accepts a numerical `force` argument to be interpreted as the time to wait
-  before forcing the shutdown.
+• |Client:stop()| now accepts a numerical `timeout` argument (renamed from `force`) to be

comment_data.body: `exit_timeout` is only indirectly related to this parameter. And as mentioned, if this is renamed, then `timeout=false` is a strange way for the caller to say "don't force". Whereas `force=int` as a way to opt-in to a timeout seems reasonable.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1653,7 +1653,7 @@ Lua module: vim.lsp.client                                        *lsp-client*
                                 See |Client:notify()|.
       • {cancel_request}        (`fun(self: vim.lsp.Client, id: integer): boolean`)
                                 See |Client:cancel_request()|.
-      • {stop}                  (`fun(self: vim.lsp.Client, force: boolean|integer?)`)
+      • {stop}                  (`fun(self: vim.lsp.Client, timeout: integer|boolean?)`)

comment_data.body: Sound fair. I'll make the change.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1653,7 +1653,7 @@ Lua module: vim.lsp.client                                        *lsp-client*
                                 See |Client:notify()|.
       • {cancel_request}        (`fun(self: vim.lsp.Client, id: integer): boolean`)
                                 See |Client:cancel_request()|.
-      • {stop}                  (`fun(self: vim.lsp.Client, force: boolean|integer?)`)
+      • {stop}                  (`fun(self: vim.lsp.Client, timeout: integer|boolean?)`)

@@ -1653,7 +1653,7 @@ Lua module: vim.lsp.client                                        *lsp-client*
                                 See |Client:notify()|.
       • {cancel_request}        (`fun(self: vim.lsp.Client, id: integer): boolean`)
                                 See |Client:cancel_request()|.
-      • {stop}                  (`fun(self: vim.lsp.Client, force: boolean|integer?)`)
+      • {stop}                  (`fun(self: vim.lsp.Client, timeout: integer|boolean?)`)

comment_data.body: let's leave this explicit. that is clearer, and also avoids mistakes if we change our minds again.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -587,7 +587,7 @@ function lsp.enable(name, enable)
   else
     for _, nm in ipairs(names) do
       for _, client in ipairs(lsp.get_clients({ name = nm })) do
-        client:stop(client.exit_timeout)
+        client:stop()

@@ -587,7 +587,7 @@ function lsp.enable(name, enable)
   else
     for _, nm in ipairs(names) do
       for _, client in ipairs(lsp.get_clients({ name = nm })) do
-        client:stop(client.exit_timeout)
+        client:stop()

@@ -1144,7 +1144,7 @@ api.nvim_create_autocmd('VimLeavePre', {
     log.info('exit_handler', active_clients)
 
     for _, client in pairs(active_clients) do
-      client:stop(client.exit_timeout)
+      client:stop()

comment_regular_data.body:
> make `client:stop()` default to `self.exit_timeout` instead of `false`.

Was this discussed somewhere? Why are we changing the default?

I don't have any strong opinion but want to check if @mfussenegger or others do. @neovim/lsp

> > make `client:stop()` default to `self.exit_timeout` instead of `false`.
> 
> Was this discussed somewhere? Why are we changing the default?

It was not discussed, so we should definitely have it here. I just think it makes sense now that it's "internally" the default. And without the change it makes `client:stop()` an outlier.

Most uses of `:stop()` benefit from inheriting the default from `exit_timeout`, and the consistency is nice. Plus, it's really simple to revert to old behavior if needed with `:stop(false)`.

> I don't have any strong opinion but want to check if @mfussenegger or others do.

I don't mind it defaulting to the client.exit_timeout value, but the overall default should remain at `false`. Not a time value.

This also seems to cause CI issues already. See https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/36795

> I don't mind it defaulting to the client.exit_timeout value, but the overall default should remain at `false`. Not a time value.

I still believe that the default should be a large number (large enough to prevent file corruption of well-behaving servers, while still improving the behavior of frozen servers), but now that the default can be easily configured, I think the default matters much less. I'd be fine changing the default back to `false` if you feel strongly about it, although I still disagree. There's definitely a good argument to changing it back.

> This also seems to cause CI issues already. See #36795

I don't believe this is relevant. The CI issue is caused by a bug in the timer logic. Changing the default just surfaced the bug.

> I'd be fine changing the default back to false if you feel strongly about it, although I still disagree.

Yes I insist. We didn't end up with the default for no reason. We had issue reports about file corruption. We had issue reports about slow nvim shutdown when we had a blocking timeout on exit. No need to walk in circles here and learn the same lessons again.


But I should add that https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/36788#issuecomment-3603058170 makes me think that coupling the `client:stop()` to the exit timeout might not be the right thing to do.

Stopping a client as part of a restart process has different requirements than stopping a client as part of exiting vim.

> > I'd be fine changing the default back to false if you feel strongly about it, although I still disagree.
> 
> Yes I insist. We didn't end up with the default for no reason. We had issue reports about file corruption. We had issue reports about slow nvim shutdown when we had a blocking timeout on exit. No need to walk in circles here and learn the same lessons again.

You've convinced me. I've opened #36811 to change the default back to `false`.

> But I should add that [#36788 (comment)](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/36788#issuecomment-3603058170) makes me think that coupling the `client:stop()` to the exit timeout might not be the right thing to do.

Would you mind elaborating? I'm not sure I see why not coupling them is useful.

> Stopping a client as part of a restart process has different requirements than stopping a client as part of exiting vim.

`exit_timeout` is already used in exiting vim. This simply expands the default from just the behavior from "restarting" to more generally be "stopping". I think the behavior when exiting vim might be worth changing, since you are right, it has different requirements. I think that's out of scope for this PR though, as this PR would not change that behavior.

Still need a Problem statement here that says what problem  is being solved. Haven't seen a case made for why this default is changing.

We have added the functionality so callers can opt-in, that's quite an improvement. Changing the default is a much bigger blast-radius for an unclear gain.

> We have added the functionality so callers can opt-in, that's quite an improvement. Changing the default is a much bigger blast-radius for an unclear gain.

While it does change the default, the default of `self.exit_timeout` is now `false` as of #36811, so the blast-radius is only for lsp configurations where `exit_timeout` is manually set. If a `vim.lsp.config` call is explicitly configuring the server to be killed after a timeout, then it follows that this setting should be used in nearly all places that `:stop()` is used for that server, since it was set that way for a reason. I don't expect this to break anything, as I would assume most plugins/users would want to respect this option. Plugins/user which have uniquely specific behavior can still override this change by manually specifying `force`, but I don't see a reason for us to ignore this configuration option by default.

> If a `vim.lsp.config` call is explicitly configuring the server to be killed after a timeout, then it follows that this setting should be used in nearly all places that `:stop()` is used for that server, since it was set that way for a reason.

That framing makes sense. And is the kind of sentence that should be in the "Problem" statement. Please do so in the future, it saves time. I updated it in this PR.

> Please do so in the future, it saves time.

Will do. Thanks for the feedback.

title: feat(lsp): `Client:stop()` defaults to `exit_timeout`
